I think in the past one of the biggest things we've had to deal I mean so first
of all scale makes everything hard and as you grow you find new bottlenecks one of the things we ran into very early on
I'm talking like 2018 2019 is as we became a bit more popular
we started getting hit by dos attacks and not just at the HTTP layer but at L4
as well at the TCP Lair where we we had never encountered that kind of volume
before and we realized that this was partly one of the reasons we decided not
to do bare metal we realized that AWS and gcp and Cloud flare they've dealt
with these problems before and they're really good at dealing with low-level dos attacks and instead of building all
of that functionality out ourselves we decided to change our architecture significantly and focus much more on
bringing Cloud flare into the mix and relying more on the larger Cloud providers to give us those basic
building blocks but we were it was a very big change for us to make and because of these attacks in the early
days we went down more often than I would have liked I'm a little confused there because you're using say cloud flare to handle a Dos how does that

running on equinex metal for some time and that's where we ran into this and we
were still using AWS and and gcp and so I think that was a big one the other Big Challenge was with gke or early on we
started using gke and we quickly realized that we were
actually at least in US West one for GK we were their largest cluster by certain
axes and that led to a ton of bugs that we found in GK and we were actually so
this is a an interesting story um okay I'll get into it so we participated in

we had won and we were going to present in the final round on October 4th and at
midnight I started getting paged and we were four people then and three
Engineers went designer I was one of the engineers so we I started getting page midnight and suddenly our GK control
plane stops responding and it's down and we have no idea what's going on we the

then four hours later at you know 5:00 a.m. Pacific it goes down again I'm on a
call with a Google engineer and this person says well actually if we restart
your control plan again I guarantee that it will be fine I'm like you you can't give me guarantees around software but

obviously it went down and then we finally finally managed to get hold of someone who realized what the problem
was which was we had upgraded the control plane and the new version had a bug that was spewing logs onto the disc
for the control plane nodes themselves and those discs were filling up so after
a while the control plane just had no dis face to do anything and so it was like an internal bug and that's on the

there's there's a lot of opinions but hardly anyone shares how they're actually doing it right there's a lot of

actually uh integrates and operates at a scale like you know tens of thousands of
different customers in different environments running different applications how does that actually architecturally look for you I think the
short answer is it continues to evolve and it depends on what our customers
need how we scale but at the very high level obviously name spaces are a good way to isolate things but also depending
on a customer scale you can imagine like a whole kubernetes cluster that is kind of dedicated to them but our customers
don't really they can figure out we're running on kubernetes if they list all the environment variables they see
what's going on so we don't hide behind that fact but we've had to put in a
bunch of security measures in place that allow us to run multi-tenant clusters
and name space isolation is just one of them there's a lot of Docker and set
comp and app armor level changes we've made uh or containery level annotations and things like that that allow us to do
this in a way that is safe and secure we have to do things in a way that is
boring and and we can't really go for like the
coolest Tech that is out there like kubernetes and kubernetes because we we
need to make sure that our customers are not affected by whatever bugs that might occur in those in those newer systems we
have talked about some of those things like kubernetes and kubernetes virtual cuets and our Engineers are they keep an
eye on those things but at the end of the day I think the foundation for us is
to try to make it so that each customer is completely isolated through a variety
of means but not necessarily at the cluster level so we have multi-end
clusters at that's the core of it that's always like one of those concerns because there's components or or
resources inside of kubernetes that aren't multi- tenantable there's plenty of things that are globally viewed
inside of a cluster and sharing that with multiple people you have to be very strict on how you isolat those things
together and make sure that one does not interfere or or consume resources or do something to another one in that
environment yeah absolutely and like I said I think this continues to evolve
and we've had I mean obviously Docker or just container capabilities are a great way to figure out what people can or
cannot do on the platform and so we rely a lot on that we rely a lot on other
kinds of protection mechanisms but what we've learned is actually the the weak links aren't at the container isol level
the weak links are often when you work with Cloud providers the weak links are often in The Primitives that the cloud
providers might expose themselves um so you know you have IM am and you have some workload running on a machine that
that can contact your control plane database and you want to make sure that
parts of your system are completely isolated from your own control plane I'm not talking about the kubernetes control
plane but you still want to be able to run your own code close to the user code
and there's a lot of complexity involved in that that we've learned to build around and kubernetes control planes are
shared obviously as a customer you cannot access the render kubernetes
control plane there's also isolation by by default in that we have the workloads
that customers have on render they don't run on machines that are directly
accessible over the Internet so those machines don't have public IP addresses everything is behind that g ways and
that allows us to control traffic and isolation a little bit better as well so
we're not like customers don't have to worry about script kitties trying to look for open ports on their apps and
everything is behind our routing and not balancing layer and then you know there's firewall rules on top and stuff
like that so I think that is where you often find issues there's also this notion of shared load balancing and
shared router layers and early on very early on we ran into cases where One
customer went viral and brought our load balancers down because yeah right and so
